en_first_half: "Had he been only in a violent fever, you would not have despised him half so much. Confess, Marianne,
en_second_half: is not there something interesting to you in the flushed cheek, hollow eye, and quick pulse of a fever?"
en_results: for if he had been in a fair way to make a good recovery by the end of the week, you would have gone on pitying
en_results_raw: for if he had been in a fair way to make a good recovery by the end of the week, you would have gone on pitying him and thinking him a fine young man, and been as much concerned for him as you could be for one of your real friends, or any of your acquaintance that you love as you love Edward. But he is the husband of your sister; he has married a woman of inferior understanding to yours; and is therefore, in your opinion, as much below you as in fortune. But, Marianne, though you value not him, you must value the very love he bears you, and be somewhat concerned at his exposure to the severe weather, which seems wholly to have taken him by surprise. His situation, besides, is a very helpless one; for though he seems at present in no danger, the tenderness of the brain may be such as to make him by and by liable to very dreadful sufferings; and though he may not die, he may be so altered as to be not one jot better than if he did, if he is to remain in his present state of stupid languor, without a power to think or remember, or any wish to do either. In that wretched state, unable to speak, to move, scarce to breathe, and all his faculties locked up, he must be so wretched! And if he were to live on in that manner for years, perhaps for ever, how dreadful would be his prospect! The sufferings of the present moment could never be forgotten. I do not pretend to say that I can do much; everybody must feel; but I am convinced that I can do more than anybody else. I have a stronger desire; and I should get the better of it; I could sit with him, and read to him, or only be in the room with him; and that would be something. I am persuaded I could be of some use; and that a little trouble would be well bestowed; and that I am not now thinking of his future good. My care would at least be some object to him; and that would be a great happiness. I could support his head; I could moisten his lips, and cool his forehead; yes, and I could be the means of saving him; and he would know it.

en_first_half: "I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes," said Elinor, "in a total misapprehension of character in some point or other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or stupid than they really are,
en_second_half: and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge."
en_results: and I have usually found that I have been deceived by some exaggerated or distorted representation of them, which has led me to form an opinion that has no foundation in reality. It is a common error, I believe, to judge of people's
en_results_raw: and I have usually found that I have been deceived by some exaggerated or distorted representation of them, which has led me to form an opinion that has no foundation in reality. It is a common error, I believe, to judge of people's characters from a few partial and imperfect observations, and to suppose that we can form a just estimate of their dispositions and qualities from a slight acquaintance. But experience has taught me that this is a very uncertain and fallible method of judging, and that it is much safer to suspend our opinion until we have had more opportunities of observing their conduct and behavior. I have known people who have been considered as very grave and serious, who have turned out to be quite frivolous and silly, and others who have been thought to be very stupid, who have proved to be highly intelligent and ingenious. It is a great mistake to judge of people by their appearance or by a few superficial qualities, and it is only by a long and intimate acquaintance that we can form a just and accurate estimate of their characters.

Me he encontrado con personas que al principio parecían ser muy serias, pero que resultaron tener un gran sentido del humor, y con otras que parecían muy amigables, pero que en realidad eran muy reservadas. Es importante no juzgar a las personas por su apariencia o por lo que otros dicen de ellas, sino por sus acciones y su comportamiento. De esta manera, podemos evitar cometer errores y formarnos una opinión más precisa de los demás. Además, es importante recordar que todos tenemos diferentes facetas y que no siempre mostramos nuestra verdadera personalidad en todo momento. La clave es ser paciente y no sacar conclusiones precipitadas sobre las personas que nos rodean.

The feelings that it awakens are too deep, too sacred, to be expressed in the cold, calculating language of criticism. They are the whispers of the heart, the sighs of the soul, the echoes of a thousand tender memories. And it is this, I believe, that makes the love of nature so essential to our well-being, so necessary to our happiness. For in its presence, we are reminded of the beauty, the wonder, and the mystery of life itself. We are drawn out of ourselves, and our petty cares and troubles, into a world of grandeur, of majesty, of awe-inspiring beauty. And it is this, I think, that makes the love of nature so enduring, so unchanging, so essential to our very existence.

en_first_half: Sir John never came to the Dashwoods without either inviting them to dine at the park the next day, or to drink tea with them that evening.

en_results: His arrival was always a signal for merriment; and with the kindness of a true friend, he always brought some little offering of game or fruit from his own estate. The
en_results_raw: His arrival was always a signal for merriment; and with the kindness of a true friend, he always brought some little offering of game or fruit from his own estate. The gentlemen would often accompany him back to the park, and spend the evening with him, while the ladies would either join them there, or remain at home, enjoying the quiet of their own fireside. On one of these occasions, as they were all sitting in the parlour at the Dashwoods', Sir John began to talk of his plans for the improvement of the park, and his schemes for the amusement of his friends during the coming winter. He was particularly anxious to have the Dashwoods' opinion on the subject, and begged them to tell him frankly what they thought of his ideas. Marianne, who had been listening with great interest, could not help but express her enthusiasm for the plan, and suggested several improvements of her own, which Sir John was delighted to hear. Elinor, on the other hand, was more cautious in her praise, and ventured to suggest that some of the schemes might be rather too ambitious, and that it would be wise to consider the expense and the practicality of the plans before putting them into action. Sir John listened attentively to their opinions, and thanked them for their candour, assuring them that he valued their advice above that of anyone else. The evening wore on, and the conversation turned to other subjects, but the Dashwoods could not help but feel grateful for the kindness and generosity of their friend, and for the pleasure of his company, which always brought such joy and warmth into their lives.

en_results_raw: attach much importance to it. But they would be still more so, if the comfort of both were as well provided for, as the felicity of one. If Augustus could be as happy in following with his heart what is designed for him by his friends, as I am in following what my heart dictates for myself, our prospects would be most delightful, and our satisfaction in each other's welfare would know no bounds. But I must not indulge these fancies. It is more consonant with the experience I have had of life, to expect that our happiness will be but partial, and our trials many. Yet, I do not mean to repine at my fate, or to suppose that I have any right to expect an exemption from the common lot of humanity. I am willing to take the chance of life as it is, and to make the best of it, as it comes. And I am the more disposed to do so, from the reflection that I have no reason to suppose that my lot will be harder than that of others. I have, indeed, my share of anxieties and cares, but they are not peculiar to myself. Every one has their own troubles, and their own way of bearing them. And I have no doubt that I shall find mine, as others do, in the common occurrences of life, and in the exercise of those virtues which are necessary to make us happy. But I must not forget that I am not alone in this world. I have those who are dear to me, and whose happiness is bound up in mine. And I must consider their feelings, as well as my own, in all that I do. I must not be selfish, and think only of my own gratification, but I must consider what will be for the good of all. And this, I am convinced, will be the best way to secure my own happiness, as well as that of those who are dear to me.

She rose from her seat, and walked to the window, where she stood for some time, struggling to compose her mind, and to calm the tumultuous emotions that agitated her breast. The letter, which had been the cause of this disturbance, was still clutched in her hand, and as she stood there, she felt an almost irresistible impulse to tear it into a thousand pieces, and scatter them to the winds. But she restrained herself, and after a time, she returned to her seat, and sat down, with a determination to read the letter once more, and to endeavour to understand the motives that had induced the writer to pen such a cruel and heartless epistle. As she read, her indignation and anger gradually gave way to a deep and sorrowful pity for the man, who could so callously disregard the feelings of another, and she felt a sense of wonder at the strange and unaccountable nature of human beings, who could be capable of such contradictions. She thought of the many times she had seen him, of the pleasant words he had spoken, of the kindly acts he had performed, and she could not help but feel a sense of sadness and regret, that one who had seemed so gentle and so kind, could prove to be so false and so cruel.

en_results: What is the use of having a good understanding, and a superior temper, if you do not exert them to
en_results_raw: What is the use of having a good understanding, and a superior temper, if you do not exert them to preserve your own life, and the happiness of those who depend on you? You are now in a state of such nervous debility, that you are not equal to any exertion; but I entreat you to make an effort, and try to get out of this house, and take some exercise, for your own sake, and for the sake of those who are most dear to you. A walk, a ride, a little fresh air, would do you good; and I am sure you would find it so, if you would only try. Do not let your spirits be depressed by the melancholy of the weather; it is but a passing cloud, and the sun will shine brightly again. You must not give way to these feelings of despair, but strive to overcome them, and to find comfort in the thought that you are not alone in your sorrow. Your family, your friends, are all anxious to help you, and to share your burdens; and I am sure that, with their assistance, you will be able to bear your troubles, and to emerge from them stronger and wiser than before.

en_results_raw: to a later period - and your attachment had been strengthened by years of confidence and affection. Every view of the subject relative to your brother's situation leads to the same conclusion - that it is a most fortunate one for you. You have escaped the misery of being connected to a man who would have made you miserable, and who would have been a perpetual source of unhappiness to you and your family. You have also escaped the danger of being drawn into a connection with a family who would have been unworthy of you, and who would have brought you nothing but trouble and distress. Your mother, too, must be relieved by the discovery, for she would have been deeply grieved by the knowledge of your brother's true character, and would have suffered much in seeing you unhappy. And as for you, Marianne, you must now see the necessity of being cautious and prudent in your attachments, and of not allowing your feelings to carry you away too hastily. You must learn to distinguish between a romantic and a rational attachment, and to be guided by reason and judgment in your choice of a partner for life. This is a lesson which you must learn, and which will be of the utmost importance to your future happiness.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

Her mother was anxious to show a distinction in her favour, and to make her feel that she was considered and preferred. Marianne was to be treated with all the indulgence of a child, and was to have every comfort and every pleasure provided for her. But in the midst of all this indulgence, she was to be reminded of the one thing which she could not have, and which she most desired. She was to be made to feel that she was not to be trusted, and that she was not worthy of confidence. Her mother was to be the one to decide what was best for her, and she was to be guided by her mother's opinion, without being allowed to have any opinion of her own. Marianne felt that this was not right, and that she was being treated unfairly. She felt that she was old enough to know what was best for herself, and that she should be allowed to make her own decisions. But she was not allowed to express her feelings, and was forced to submit to her mother's will. The visit was to be a trial for her, and she was to be tested in many ways. She was to be forced to confront her feelings, and to decide what she truly wanted. She was to be made to see that she had been foolish to think that she could ever be happy with a man who did not love her. And she was to be reminded that she was not worthy of love, and that she would never find true happiness. The visit was to be a difficult and painful experience for Marianne, but it was also to be a valuable lesson for her. She was to learn that she was not the centre of the universe, and that she was not entitled to have everything she wanted. She was to learn that sometimes, the things we want most are not the things that are best for us, and that we must be willing to make sacrifices in order to find true happiness.

She was not, indeed, very clever, nor very wise, nor very witty; but she was very good-natured, and very good-humoured; and she was always ready to do what she could to oblige her sister, and to make her happy. She was, in fact, a very pleasant and a very agreeable companion; and though she was not very brilliant, nor very distinguished, she was very well liked, and very well respected, by all who knew her.

en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."
